newsitem.title: CHINA: HONG KONG STOCKS END WEAK AS PROPERTY STOCKS FALL.
newsitem.headline: HONG KONG STOCKS END WEAK AS PROPERTY STOCKS FALL.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks ended weak on Tuesday, reversing gains made earlier in the day, as a rising U.S. long bond yield and an increase in mortgage lending rates by two major banks prompted a slide in property shares.
The Hang Seng Index fell 77.06 points, or 0.47 percent, to close at 16,383.41 after rising to an early high of 16,660.76.
Turnover was a heavy HK$27.93 billion compared with HK$22.99 billion on Monday.
"The market is having a bit of trouble at these levels," said Richard Verin, head of equity trading at Credit Suisse First Boston.
"Standard Chartered and Hongkong Bank raised mortgage rates and when mortgage rates go up it is not positive for the property sector," he said.
Sun Hung Kai Properties tumbled HK$2.00 to HK$100.00, Cheung Kong fell HK$1.50 to HK$92.25 and New World Development dropped HK$1.00 at HK$56.50.
Hongkong Bank and Standard Chartered Bank recently raised their mortgage rates by 25 basis points to 9.25 percent.
A rise of 30.89 points in the Dow industrials overnight to 8,062.11 had fuelled sharp gains in the local market in early trade, reversing a sharp slide in prices registered on Monday.
But with a slew of U.S. economic data due out this week ahead of next Tuesday's U.S. Federal Reserve policy-setting meeting, brokers said investors were still cautious.
Economic figures due out this week include July producer and consumer prices and industrial production.
"If there is a rate rise, that is not good for property," said Rory McAllister at HSBC James Capal.
"There is a chance that mortgage rates are going up which is keeping the index down," he added.
Hang Seng Bank also pulled the Hang Seng Index down with a loss of HK$2.00 to HK$106.50.
The stock surged HK$5.50 on Monday on speculation that a Chinese party might buy a stake in the bank.
But HSBC Holdings followed through on an overnight rally in London and added HK$3.00 to HK$273.00.
H-shares soared on Tuesday as investors continued to speculate on future restructuring in the sector.
The index of Hong Kong-listed Chinese enterprises rose 76.27 points, or 5.62 percent, to 1,433.95.
Hang Seng Index August futures fell 50 points to 16,290.
